baseline_groups.claim_summary: Counties with higher pre-VRA Black population shares that were covered by VRA Section 5 experienced larger relative declines in Black arrest rates (treatment = black_share60 x coverage). VRA reduced discriminatory policing.
baseline_groups.notes: Main claim from Table 1 of the paper. Treatment is interaction of black_share60_proxy and VRA Section 5 coverage. Outcome is long-difference in log total Black arrest rates (sheriff + police combined). Baseline uses basic controls (pop, black_share) with state FE and judicial division clustering. The proxy for black_share60 was constructed from child population data rather than full Census data.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: VRA treatment had no significant effect on white arrest rates, serving as a placebo/falsification test for the main claim.
baseline_groups.notes: White arrest rates as placebo. The paper argues the VRA should only reduce discriminatory policing against Blacks, not affect white arrests. This is a falsification test for G1, not an independent claim. Baseline_white uses same treatment but with white arrest outcome.

global_notes: This paper uses cross-sectional OLS on long-differenced outcomes. The replication was constructed from raw public data since intermediate datasets were not available. The treatment variable (black_share60_proxy x coverage) is an approximation using child population nonwhite share as a proxy for black_share60. Coefficients should be interpreted for sign and approximate magnitude rather than exact replication. 78 total specifications. The paper's main finding is that VRA coverage reduced Black arrest rates in counties with higher Black population shares.
